briefdescription.para: When Entity.init() is called, onInit() is called on all of it's children.

simplesect.para: This should only be used internally or by advanced users. Misuse can cause undefined behavior
This uses an OpenGL function and must be called in a thread with an OpenGL context. Otherwise, an error will be thrown.

parameterdescription.para: If the current thread does not have an OpenGL context

briefdescription.para: Should be called a by Entity when MACE.update() is called.

detaileddescription.para: Calls onUpdate().

Overriding this function is dangerous. Only do it if you know what you are doing. Instead, override onUpdate()

If the property Entity::INIT is false, meaning init() was not called.

briefdescription.para: Bit location representing whether an Entity is dead.

detaileddescription.para:
If true, any Entity holding it will remove it and call kill()
Entity::getProperty(unsigned int)

briefdescription.para: Property defining if an Entity can be updated and rendered.

detaileddescription.para:
If this is true, Entity::update() and Entity::render() will not be called by it's parent.
Entity::getProperty(unsigned int)

briefdescription.para: Flag representing whether an Entity's init() function has been called.

detaileddescription.para: If destroy() or update() is called and this is false, an InitializationError is thrown.

If init() is called and this is true, an InitializationError is thrown.
Entity::getProperty(unsigned int)

briefdescription.para: Flag representing whether this Entity is dirty and it's positions needs to be recalculated.

detaileddescription.para:
This will become true under the following conditions:
The Entity has been changed. Assume that any non-const function other than render() and update() will trigger this condition.
The window is resized, moved, or created
Other classes that inherit Entity can also set this to true via Entity::setProperty(Byte, bool)

When an Entity becomes dirty, it will propogate up the tree. It's parent will become dirty, it's parent will become dirty, etc. This will continue until it reaches the highest level Entity, which is usually the GraphicsContext. From there, it will decide what to do based on it's Entity::DIRTY flag.
Certain GraphicsContexts may only render when something is dirty, heavily increasing performance in applications with little moving objects.
Additionally, an Entity that is considered dirty will have it's sslBuffer updated on the GPU side.
